Detailed Description

Macro Definition Documentation

◆ AM_HAL_FLASH_ADDR

#define AM_HAL_FLASH_ADDR   0x00000000

Some helpful flash values and macros.

For Apollo3P, flash is arranged internally as 4 instances of 512K each, which are controlled (am_hal_pwrctrl.h) as 2 domains of 1M each.

◆ AM_HAL_FLASH_ADDR2ABSPAGE

#define AM_HAL_FLASH_ADDR2ABSPAGE (   addr)    ( addr >> 13 )

Convert an absolute flash address to an absolute page number.

◆ AM_HAL_FLASH_ADDR2INST

#define AM_HAL_FLASH_ADDR2INST (   addr)    ( ( addr >> 19 ) & (AM_HAL_FLASH_NUM_INSTANCES - 1) )

Convert an absolute flash address to an instance.

◆ AM_HAL_FLASH_ADDR2PAGE

#define AM_HAL_FLASH_ADDR2PAGE (   addr)    ( ( addr >> 13 ) & 0x3F )

Convert an absolute flash address to a page number relative to the instance.

◆ AM_HAL_FLASH_INFO_SIGNATURE0

#define AM_HAL_FLASH_INFO_SIGNATURE0   0x48EAAD88

Define the customer info signature data (at AM_HAL_FLASH_INFO_ADDR). These bits must exist in the customer info space in order for many of the security and protection functions to work.

◆ CYCLESPERITER

#define CYCLESPERITER   (AM_HAL_CLKGEN_FREQ_MAX_MHZ / 3)

Given an integer number of microseconds, convert to a value representing the number of am_hal_flash_delay() cycles that will provide that amount of delay. This macro is designed to take into account some of the call overhead and latencies.

e.g. To provide a 10us delay: am_hal_flash_delay( FLASH_CYCLES_US(10) );

As of SDK 2.1, burst mode is accounted for in am_hal_flash_delay().

The FLASH_CYCLES_US macro assumes:

  • Burst or normal mode operation.
  • If cache is not enabled, use FLASH_CYCLES_US_NOCACHE() instead.

◆ FLASH_CYCLES_US

#define FLASH_CYCLES_US (   n)    ((n * CYCLESPERITER) + 0)

◆ FLASH_CYCLES_US_NOCACHE

#define FLASH_CYCLES_US_NOCACHE (   n)    ( (n == 0) ? 0 : (n * CYCLESPERITER) - 5)

◆ ISADDRFLASH

#define ISADDRFLASH (   x)    (x <= (AM_HAL_FLASH_LARGEST_VALID_ADDR & ~0x3))

◆ ISADDRSRAM

#define ISADDRSRAM (   x)
Value:
((x >= AM_HAL_FLASH_SRAM_ADDR) && \
(x <= (AM_HAL_FLASH_SRAM_LARGEST_VALID_ADDR & ~0x3)))
AM_HAL_FLASH_SRAM_LARGEST_VALID_ADDR
#define AM_HAL_FLASH_SRAM_LARGEST_VALID_ADDR
Definition: am_hal_flash.h:78
AM_HAL_FLASH_SRAM_ADDR
#define AM_HAL_FLASH_SRAM_ADDR
Some helpful SRAM values and macros.
Definition: am_hal_flash.h:76

Macros to determine whether a given address is a valid internal flash or SRAM address.

Typedef Documentation

◆ g_am_hal_flash_t

typedef struct am_hal_flash_helper_struct g_am_hal_flash_t

Structure of pointers to helper functions invoking flash operations.

The functions we are pointing to here are in the Apollo 3 integrated BOOTROM.

◆ WakeWAfunc_t

typedef void(* WakeWAfunc_t) (void)

Prototype for the workaround function.

Function Documentation

◆ am_hal_flash_clear_bits()

int am_hal_flash_clear_bits ( uint32_t  ui32ProgramKey,
uint32_t *  pui32Addr,
uint32_t  ui32BitMask 
)

This clears the specified bits in the addressed flash word.

Parameters
ui32ProgramKey- The programming key, AM_HAL_FLASH_PROGRAM_KEY.
pui32Addr- Pointer to word aligned flash word to program into
ui32BitMask- The bits to be cleared

This function will clear one of more bits in a word in main flash. This function is mainly used when the same word is to be written multiple times few bits at a time, between erase cycle

Note
Interrupts are active during execution of this function. Any interrupt taken could cause execution errors. Please see the IMPORTANT note under Detailed Description above for more details.
Note
We can reprogram a bit in flash to 0 only once. This function takes care of not re-clearing bits if they are already programmed as 0
Returns
0 for success, non-zero for failure.

Note: See am_hal_flash_program_main() for further details on return codes.

◆ am_hal_flash_copy_protect_check()

bool am_hal_flash_copy_protect_check ( uint32_t *  pui32StartAddress,
uint32_t *  pui32StopAddress 
)

This function checks copy protection for a range of flash chunks.

Parameters
pui32StartAddress- Starting address in flash.
pui32StopAddress- Ending address in flash.

This function will check copy protection bits for a range of flash chunks it expects all chunks in the range to be protected.

Note
Each flash chunk contains 16KBytes and corresponds to one bit in the protection register. Set the bit to zero to enable protection.
Returns
  • false for at least one chunk in the covered range is not protected,
  • true if all chunks in the covered range are protected.

◆ am_hal_flash_copy_protect_set()

int32_t am_hal_flash_copy_protect_set ( uint32_t  ui32InfoKey,
uint32_t *  pui32StartAddress,
uint32_t *  pui32StopAddress 
)

This function sets copy protection for a range of flash chunks.

Parameters
ui32InfoKey- The customer INFO space programming key
pui32StartAddress- Starting address in flash to begin protection.
pui32StopAddress- Ending address in flash to stop protection.

This function will set copy protection bits for a range of flash chunks

Note
Each flash chunk contains 16KBytes and corresponds to one bit in the protection register. Set the bit to zero to enable protection.
Note
Interrupts are active during execution of this function. Any interrupt taken could cause execution errors. Please see the IMPORTANT note under Detailed Description above for more details.
Returns
  • 0 for success.
  • 0x400000 if the protection bits were already programmed (mask the return value with 0x3FFFFF to ignore this case and treat as success).
  • Otherwise, non-zero for failure.

Note: See am_hal_flash_program_info() for further details on return codes.

◆ am_hal_flash_customer_info_signature_check()

bool am_hal_flash_customer_info_signature_check ( void  )

Check that the customer info bits are valid.

Use this function to test the state of the 128 valid bits at the beginning of customer info space. If these are not set correctly then the customer protection bits in the INFO space will not be honored by the hardware.

Returns
true if valid.

◆ am_hal_flash_delay()

void am_hal_flash_delay ( uint32_t  ui32Iterations)

Use the bootrom to implement a spin loop.

Parameters
ui32Iterations- Number of iterations to delay.

Use this function to implement a CPU busy waiting spin loop without cache or delay uncertainties.

Notes for Apollo3:

  • The ROM-based function executes at 3 cycles per iteration plus the normal function call, entry, and exit overhead and latencies.
  • Cache settings affect call overhead. However, the cache does not affect the time while inside the BOOTROM function.
  • The function accounts for burst vs normal mode, along with some of the overhead encountered with executing the function itself (such as the check for burst mode).
  • Use of the FLASH_CYCLES_US() or FLASH_CYCLES_US_NOCACHE() macros for the ui32Iterations parameter will result in approximate microsecond timing.
  • The parameter ui32Iterations==0 is allowed but is still incurs a delay.

Example:

  • MCU operating at 48MHz -> 20.83 ns / cycle
  • Therefore each iteration (once inside the bootrom function) will consume 62.5ns (non-burst-mode).
Note
Interrupts are not disabled during execution of this function. Therefore, any interrupt taken will affect the delay timing.

◆ am_hal_flash_delay_status_change()

uint32_t am_hal_flash_delay_status_change ( uint32_t  ui32usMaxDelay,
uint32_t  ui32Address,
uint32_t  ui32Mask,
uint32_t  ui32Value 
)

Delays for a desired amount of cycles while also waiting for a status to change a value.

Parameters
ui32usMaxDelay- Maximum number of ~1uS delay loops.
ui32Address- Address of the register for the status change.
ui32Mask- Mask for the status change.
ui32Value- Target value for the status change.

This function will delay for approximately the given number of microseconds while checking for a status change, exiting when either the given time has expired or the status change is detected.

Returns
  • 0 = timeout.
  • 1 = status change detected.

◆ am_hal_flash_delay_status_check()

uint32_t am_hal_flash_delay_status_check ( uint32_t  ui32usMaxDelay,
uint32_t  ui32Address,
uint32_t  ui32Mask,
uint32_t  ui32Value,
bool  bIsEqual 
)

Delays for a desired amount of cycles while also waiting for a status to equal OR not-equal to a value.

Parameters
ui32usMaxDelay- Maximum number of ~1uS delay loops.
ui32Address- Address of the register for the status change.
ui32Mask- Mask for the status change.
ui32Value- Target value for the status change.
bIsEqual- Check for equal if true; not-equal if false.

This function will delay for approximately the given number of microseconds while checking for a status change, exiting when either the given time has expired or the status change is detected.

Returns
  • 0 = timeout.
  • 1 = status change detected.

◆ am_hal_flash_erase_info()

int am_hal_flash_erase_info ( uint32_t  ui32InfoKey,
uint32_t  ui32Inst 
)

This function erases an instance of the customer INFO space.

Parameters
ui32InfoKey- The customer INFO space programming key (AM_HAL_FLASH_INFO_KEY).
ui32Inst- The flash instance, either 0 or 1.

This function will erase the the customer INFO space of the specified instance.

Note
Interrupts are active during execution of this function. Any interrupt taken could cause execution errors. Please see the IMPORTANT note under Detailed Description above for more details.
Returns
0 for success, non-zero for failure. Failing return code indicates:
  • 1 ui32InfoKey is invalid.
  • 2 ui32Inst is invalid.
  • 3 Hardware error.
  • 4 Flash controller hardware timeout.

◆ am_hal_flash_erase_main_plus_info()

int am_hal_flash_erase_main_plus_info ( uint32_t  ui32InfoKey,
uint32_t  ui32Inst

Parameters

ui32Inst- The flash instance, either 0 or 1.

This function will erase the main flash + the customer INFO space of the specified instance.

  • 1 ui32InfoKey is invalid.
  • 2 ui32Inst is invalid.
  • 3 Hardware error.
  • 4 Flash controller hardware timeout.
  • 11 Internal error.
  • 12 Internal error.
  • 13 Flash controller hardware timeout.

  • i3 Hardware error, instance i (i=0-3).
  • i4 Flash controller hardware timeout, instance i (i=0-3).
  • i01 Internal error, instance i (i=0-3).
  • i02 Internal error, instance i (i=0-3).
  • i03 Flash controller hardware timeout, instance i (i=0-3).

◆ am_hal_flash_info_program_disable()

int32_t am_hal_flash_info_program_disable ( uint32_t  ui32InfoKey,
uint32_t  ui32Mask 
)

Mask off 1 to 4 quadrants of FLASH INFO space for programming.

Use this function to set the state of the 128 valid bits at the beginning of customer info space, if needed. Then and the mask bits with the INFO space programming disable bits.

Parameters
ui32InfoKey- The customer INFO space programming key
ui32Mask- A mask of the 4 quadrants of info space where
  • bit0 = First quadrant (first 2KB).
  • bit1 = Second quadrant (second 2KB).
  • bit2 = Third quadrant (third 2KB).
  • bit3 = Fourth quadrant (fourth 2KB).
Note
This function disables only, any quadrant already disabled is not re-enabled. That is, any ui32Mask bits specified as 0 are essentially nops.
Note
Interrupts are active during execution of this function. Any interrupt taken could cause execution errors. Please see the IMPORTANT note under Detailed Description above for more details.
Returns
  • Zero for success.
  • Non-Zero for errors.

Note: See am_hal_flash_program_info() for further details on return codes.

◆ am_hal_flash_info_program_disable_get()

uint32_t am_hal_flash_info_program_disable_get ( void  )

Return a mask specifying which quadrants of customer INFO space have been disabled for programming.

Use this function to determine whether programming of customer INFO space has been disabled.

Returns
A 4-bit mask of the disabled quadrants.
  • 0xFFFFFFFF indicates an error.
  • 0x0 indicates all customer INFO space programming is enabled.
  • 0xF indicates all customer INFO space programming is disabled.
  • bit0 indicates the first customer INFO space is disabled for programming.
  • bit1 indicates the second customer INFO space is disabled for programming.
  • bit2 indicates the third customer INFO space is disabled for programming.
  • bit3 indicates the fourth customer INFO space is disabled for programming.

◆ am_hal_flash_load_ui32()

uint32_t am_hal_flash_load_ui32 ( uint32_t *  pui32Address)

Read a uint32 value from a valid memory or peripheral location.

BOOTROM resident reader, writer and delay utility functions. This function calls a function that resides BOOTROM or SRAM to do the actual read, thus completely avoiding any conflict with flash or INFO space.

Parameters
pui32Address- The location to be read.
Note
Use this function to safely read a value from peripheral or memory locations.
Returns
The value read from the given address.

This function performs a mass erase on a flash instance.

◆ am_hal_flash_page_erase()

int am_hal_flash_page_erase ( uint32_t  ui32ProgramKey,
uint32_t  ui32FlashInst,
uint32_t  ui32PageNum 
)

This function performs a page erase on a flash instance.

Parameters
ui32ProgramKey- The flash program key.
ui32FlashInst- The flash instance to reference the page number with.
ui32PageNum- The flash page relative to the specified instance.

This function will erase the desired flash page in the desired instance of flash.

Note
For Apollo3, each flash page is 8KB (or AM_HAL_FLASH_PAGE_SIZE). Each flash instance contains a maximum of 64 pages (or AM_HAL_FLASH_INSTANCE_PAGES).
Note
When given an absolute flash address, a couple of helpful macros can be utilized when calling this function. For example: am_hal_flash_page_erase(AM_HAL_FLASH_PROGRAM_KEY, AM_HAL_FLASH_ADDR2INST(ui32Addr), AM_HAL_FLASH_ADDR2PAGE(ui32Addr) );
Note
Interrupts are active during execution of this function. Any interrupt taken could cause execution errors. Please see the IMPORTANT note under Detailed Description above for more details.
Returns
0 for success, non-zero for failure. Failing return code indicates:
  • 1 ui32ProgramKey is invalid.
  • 2 ui32FlashInst is invalid.
  • 3 ui32PageNum is invalid.
  • 4 Flash controller hardware timeout.

◆ am_hal_flash_program_info()

int am_hal_flash_program_info ( uint32_t  ui32InfoKey,
uint32_t  ui32InfoInst,
uint32_t *  pui32Src,
uint32_t  ui32Offset,
uint32_t  ui32NumWords 
)

This function programs multiple words in the customer INFO space.

Parameters
ui32InfoKey- The customer INFO space key.
ui32InfoInst- The INFO space instance, 0 or 1.
*pui32Src- Pointer to word aligned array of data to program into the customer INFO space.
ui32Offset- Word offset into customer INFO space (offset of 0 is the first word, 1 is second word, etc.).
ui32NumWords- The number of words to be programmed, must not exceed AM_HAL_FLASH_INFO_SIZE/4.
Note
Interrupts are active during execution of this function. Any interrupt taken could cause execution errors. Please see the IMPORTANT note under Detailed Description above for more details.
Returns
0 for success, non-zero for failure. Failing return code indicates:
  • 1 ui32InfoKey is invalid.
  • 2 ui32InfoInst is invalid.
  • 3 ui32Offset is invalid.
  • 4 INFO addressing range would be exceeded. That is, (ui32Offset + ui32NumWords) is greater than the last valid address.
  • 5 pui32Src is invalid.
  • 6 pui32Src is invalid.
  • 7 Hardware error.
  • 8 Flash controller hardware timeout.

◆ am_hal_flash_program_main()

int am_hal_flash_program_main ( uint32_t  ui32ProgramKey,
uint32_t *  pui32Src,
uint32_t *  pui32Dst,
uint32_t  ui32NumWords 
)

This programs up to N words of the Main array on one flash instance.

Parameters
ui32ProgramKey- The programming key, AM_HAL_FLASH_PROGRAM_KEY.
pui32Src- Pointer to word aligned array of data to program into the flash instance.
pui32Dst- Pointer to the word aligned flash location where programming of the flash instance is to begin.
ui32NumWords- The number of words to be programmed.

This function will program multiple words in main flash.

Note
Interrupts are active during execution of this function. Any interrupt taken could cause execution errors. Please see the IMPORTANT note under Detailed Description above for more details.
Returns
0 for success, non-zero for failure. Failing return code indicates:
  • 1 ui32ProgramKey is invalid.
  • 2 pui32Dst is invalid.
  • 3 Flash addressing range would be exceeded. That is, (pui32Dst + (ui32NumWords * 4)) is greater than the last valid address.
  • 4 pui32Src is invalid.
  • 5 pui32Src is invalid.
  • 6 Flash controller hardware timeout.

◆ am_hal_flash_recovery()

int am_hal_flash_recovery ( uint32_t  ui32RecoveryKey)

This function erases both main flash instances + both customer INFO space instances.

Parameters
ui32RecoveryKey- The recovery key.

This function erases both main instances and both customer INFOinstances even if the customer INFO space is programmed to not be erasable. This function completely erases the flash main and info instances and wipes the SRAM. Upon completion of the erasure operations, it does a POI (power on initialization) reset.

Note
The customer key lock is enforced by this function. Therefore, the customer key must be written prior to calling otherwise, the function will fail. Therefore, always check for a return code. If the function returns, a failure has occured.
Note
Interrupts are active during execution of this function. Any interrupt taken could cause execution errors. Please see the IMPORTANT note under Detailed Description above for more details.
Returns
Does not return if successful. Returns failure code otherwise.
  • Failing return code indicates:
  • 0x00000001 ui32RecoveryKey is invalid.
  • 0x00000002 Customer key lock not set.
  • 0x00001001 Internal error.
  • 0x00001002 Internal error.
  • 0x00001003 Info erase, instance 0 - hardware error.
  • 0x00001004 Info erase, instance 0 - flash controller hardware timeout.
  • 0xi000ppee Error erasing page in instance, pp=page number, ee=error code.
    • i=2|4|6|8, instance (i/2)
    • i=3|5|7|9, instance ((i-1)/2).
    • ee=1 Internal error.
    • ee=2 Internal error.
    • ee=3 Hardware error.
    • ee=4 Flash controller hardware timeout.

◆ am_hal_flash_store_ui32()

void am_hal_flash_store_ui32 ( uint32_t *  pui32Address,
uint32_t  ui32Value 
)

Write a given uint32 value to a valid memory or peripheral location.

Parameters
pui32Address- The location to be written.
ui32Value- Value to be written
Note
Use this function to safely store a value to peripheral or memory locations.

This function calls a function that resides in BOOTROM or SRAM to do the actual write, thus completely avoiding any conflict with flash or INFO. This function safely writes to a peripheral or memory address while executing from SRAM, thus avoiding any conflict with flash or INFO space.
